Question Text: Which of the following is an example of a network layer (layer 3) protocol in the five-layer TCP/IP model?
Choices:
a. IP
b. Ethernet
c. UDP
d. TCP
LLM Explanation: IP (Internet Protocol) is a network layer (layer 3) protocol in the five-layer TCP/IP model. It is responsible for addressing, routing, and delivering packets between hosts across network boundaries. Ethernet (b) is a data link layer (layer 2) protocol, while UDP (c) and TCP (d) are transport layer (layer 4) protocols.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th ed.). Pearson.', 'Tanenbaum, A. S., & Wetherall, D. J. (2011). Computer Networks (5th ed.). Prentice Hall.']

Question Text: Which of these is an example of something that works on the application layer (layer 5 of the five-layer TCP/IP model)?
Choices:
a. A router
b. A browser
c. UDP
d. An ethernet cable
LLM Explanation: A browser is an example of an application that operates at the application layer (layer 5) of the five-layer TCP/IP model. The application layer is the topmost layer where user applications like web browsers, email clients, and file transfer programs interact with the network. Routers work at the network layer (layer 3), UDP is a transport layer (layer 4) protocol, and Ethernet cables are part of the network access layer (layer 1).
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'TCP/IP Protocol Suite, 4th Edition by Behrouz A. Forouzan']

Question Text: Which layer of the five layer TCP/IP model deals with cabling and connectors?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The application layer
LLM Explanation: The physical layer of the five layer TCP/IP model deals with the physical aspects of network communication, including cabling, connectors, and the electrical or optical signals used to transmit data. It defines the physical and electrical specifications of the network hardware and the transmission medium.
URLs: ['TCP/IP Guide: A Comprehensive, Illustrated Internet Protocols Reference by Charles M. Kozierok, 2005', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition) by James Kurose and Keith Ross, 2017', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, 2019']

Question Text: Which level of the TCP/IP five-layer model does a router operate on?
Choices:
a. The data link layer
b. The transport layer
c. The application layer
d. The network layer
LLM Explanation: A router operates at the network layer of the TCP/IP model. The network layer is responsible for addressing, routing, and delivering packets between different networks. Routers use IP addresses to make forwarding decisions and route packets to their destination networks.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: On which layer are Ethernet standards and some wireless technologies operating?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The data link layer
LLM Explanation: Ethernet standards and some wireless technologies like Wi-Fi operate at the data link layer of the OSI model. The data link layer is responsible for reliable transfer of data frames between two nodes connected by a physical layer. It provides the functional and procedural means to transfer data between network entities and might provide the means to detect and possibly correct errors that may occur in the physical layer.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_link_layer', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/ethernet/212643-osi-model-ethernet-and-ieee-802-standard.html']

Question Text: Which of these allows connections from many devices and inspects the contents of ethernet protocol data?
Choices:
a. A hub
b. A collision domain
c. A cable
d. A switch
LLM Explanation: A switch allows connections from many devices and inspects the contents of Ethernet protocol data. Switches operate at the data link layer (Layer 2) of the OSI model. They use MAC addresses to forward frames to the appropriate ports, enabling communication between devices on the same network segment. Switches maintain a MAC address table to keep track of which devices are connected to each port, allowing them to efficiently direct traffic. By inspecting the Ethernet protocol data, switches can make intelligent forwarding decisions.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-a-network-switch.html']

Question Text: What does LAN stand for?
Choices:
a. Local area network
b. Little area network
c. Large area network
d. Locally available network
LLM Explanation: LAN stands for Local Area Network. It refers to a computer network that interconnects computers within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, office building or group of nearby buildings.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_area_network', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-a-lan-local-area-network.html']

Question Text: What's a router?
Choices:
a. A physical layer device that prevents crosstalk
b. A device that knows how to forward data between independent networks.
c. A more advanced version of a switch
d. A physical layer device that allows connections for many computers at once
LLM Explanation: A router is a network device that forwards data packets between computer networks. Routers operate at the network layer (Layer 3) of the OSI model. They use headers and forwarding tables to determine the best path for forwarding the packets, and they use protocols such as ICMP to communicate with each other and configure the best route between any two hosts.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Router_(computing)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/routers/what-is-a-router.html']

Question Text: Which of these is a server?
Choices:
a. A device operating on the data link layer that connects many devices together and inspects ethernet protocol data
b. A device that forwards data between multiple networks
c. Something receiving data from something providing data
d. Something providing data to something requesting the data
LLM Explanation: A server is a device or program that provides data or services to clients that request them. This matches options c and d, which describe something that receives data requests and provides the requested data in response. Options a and b describe switches and routers respectively, which are networking devices that forward data but are not considered servers.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Server_(computing)', 'https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/network-layer/what-is-a-router/', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-a-network-switch.html']

Question Text: What kind of wiring is in cables that communicate in voltage changes that are received by the receiving device as ones and zeros?
Choices:
a. Fiber
b. Aluminum
c. Gold
d. Copper
LLM Explanation: Copper wiring is used in cables that communicate digital signals as voltage changes representing binary ones and zeros. Copper is an excellent conductor of electricity and is commonly used in network cables like Ethernet. Fiber optic cables use light pulses instead of electrical signals. Aluminum and gold are not typically used as the primary conductor in network cabling.
URLs: ['https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/Ethernet', 'https://www.comptia.org/content/guides/what-is-a-network-cable']

Question Text: What modulation type is used for computer networks?
Choices:
a. RJ45
b. Simplex communication
c. Line coding
d. Line crimping
LLM Explanation: Line coding is the modulation technique used in computer networks to convert digital data into waveforms suitable for transmission over the physical medium. It involves representing the digital signal with voltage, current, or light variations. RJ45 is a connector type, simplex is a communication mode, and crimping is the process of attaching connectors to cables.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'Data and Computer Communications, 10th Edition by William Stallings']

Question Text: What is the difference between full duplex and half duplex?
Choices:
a. Half duplex occurs when hubs are in use; full duplex occurs when switches are in use.
b. Full duplex allows communications in two directions at the same time; half duplex means that only one side can communicate at a time.
c. Full duplex is a form of simplex communications.
d. Full duplex is slower than half duplex.
LLM Explanation: Full duplex communication allows data to be transmitted in both directions simultaneously, meaning both devices can send and receive data at the same time. In contrast, half duplex communication only allows data transmission in one direction at a time, so while one device is transmitting, the other can only receive, and vice versa. The choice of full duplex or half duplex is not directly related to the use of hubs or switches, and full duplex is generally faster than half duplex as it allows for simultaneous two-way communication.
URLs: ['https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/ethernet/10563-full-half-duplex-csma-cd.html', 'https://www.comptia.org/content/guides/a-guide-to-network-troubleshooting/duplex-mismatch']

Question Text: The ____________ consists of devices and is responsible for sending signals between devices.
Choices:
a. network layer
b. data link layer
c. physical layer
d. modulation
LLM Explanation: The physical layer is responsible for sending signals between devices. It consists of the actual hardware and physical media used to transmit data, such as cables, connectors, network interface cards, and other devices. The physical layer defines the electrical, mechanical, and functional specifications for activating, maintaining, and deactivating the physical link between communicating devices.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: What is the most common type of cabling used for connecting computing devices?
Choices:
a. Power Cable
b. Twisted Pair Cable
c. VGA Cable
d. SATA Cable
LLM Explanation: Twisted pair cable is the most common type of cabling used for connecting computing devices, especially in Ethernet networks. It consists of pairs of insulated copper wires twisted together to reduce electromagnetic interference and crosstalk. Twisted pair cables are widely used due to their low cost, flexibility, and suitability for high-speed data transmission over short to medium distances.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press, 2019)', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross (Pearson, 2016)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-an-ethernet-cable.html']

Question Text: Which of the following are category types of Twisted Pair Ethernet cable? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP).
b. Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP).
c. Shielded Twisted Pair (STP).
d. USB Cable
LLM Explanation: Twisted pair Ethernet cables come in three main categories: Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP), Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP), and Shielded Twisted Pair (STP). UTP cables have no shielding, making them more susceptible to electromagnetic interference but also less expensive. FTP cables have foil shielding around each pair of wires to reduce crosstalk. STP cables have a metallic braid or foil that encases each pair of wires, providing better protection against EMI and crosstalk compared to UTP and FTP. USB cables are not a type of twisted pair Ethernet cable.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'Network+ Guide to Networks by Jill West, Tamara Dean, Jean Andrews']

Question Text: How many octets are there in a MAC address?
LLM Explanation: A MAC (Media Access Control) address is a unique identifier assigned to a network interface controller (NIC) for use as a network address in communications within a network segment. A MAC address is 48 bits (6 bytes) in length and is typically represented in hexadecimal notation, with each octet separated by colons or hyphens, e.g., 00:11:22:33:44:55. Therefore, there are 6 octets in a standard MAC address.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_address', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/dynamic-address-allocation-resolution/13715-42.html']

Question Text: What address is used for Ethernet broadcasts?
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet broadcast address is FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF. This is a special MAC address used to send Ethernet frames to all devices on a LAN segment. When a frame is sent to this address, all devices on that segment will receive and process it.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadcast_address#Ethernet', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: What is a cyclical redundancy check?
Choices:
a. A way for two computers to synchronize their clocks.
b. The actual data being transported by an Ethernet frame.
c. A technique that allows for multiple logical LANs to operate on the same equipment.
d. A mathematical calculation used to ensure that all data arrived intact.
LLM Explanation: A cyclical redundancy check (CRC) is a mathematical calculation used to ensure that all data arrived intact during transmission. It is an error-detecting code commonly used in digital networks and storage devices to detect accidental changes to raw data. The sending device calculates a CRC value based on the data and appends it to the message. The receiving device then performs the same calculation on the received data and compares the calculated CRC value with the one received. If they match, it indicates the data likely arrived without errors.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclic_redundancy_check', 'https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/cyclic-redundancy-checking']

Question Text: Which of the following are ways for transmitting data at the Ethernet level? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Multicast
b. Duplex
c. Broadcast
d. Unicast
LLM Explanation: At the Ethernet level, data can be transmitted in three ways:a. Multicast - sending data to a group of devicesc. Broadcast - sending data to all devices on the network d. Unicast - sending data to a single specific deviceDuplex (b) refers to the communication mode (half-duplex or full-duplex) and is not a data transmission method at the Ethernet level.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: Which of the following are parts of an Ethernet frame? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Data payload
c. EtherType field
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: An Ethernet frame consists of several fields, including:b. Data payload - The actual data being transmitted, which can be up to 1500 bytes. c. EtherType field - A two-byte field used to indicate which protocol is encapsulated in the payload (e.g., IPv4, IPv6, ARP).d. Preamble - A 7-byte field with alternating 1s and 0s used for synchronization between the sending and receiving devices.The broadcast option (a) is not a specific part of the Ethernet frame structure, but rather a type of Ethernet transmission sent to all devices on a LAN segment.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet_frame', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/8021q/17056-741-4.html']
